Introduction

Welcome to Everything SQL!

SQL stands for Structured Query Language. It is a great tool for managing databases.

Below are the multitude of things that can be done with SQL:

  • Databasing with SQL and Python with sqlite
  • SQLAlchemy
  • Also check out this SQL exercise involving a murder mystery!

The goal of this documentation is to provide a one-stop-shop of everything SQL by combining information from multiple websites. Each section will cover the syntax of various commands and a brief note of their significance. For more examples with actual data, you can scroll down to the References section. That section contains the websites used to compile this documentation together.

What you should already know

Nothing! Honestly, learning SQL can begin right now. No prerequisits needed to get started. However, this guide assumes you have the following background when it comes to combining SQL with other programs such as:

  • Some understanding of Python.
  • Access to SQL software like MySQL, PostgreSQL etc.
Syntax

One important thing to remember about SQL syntax is that it's NOT case-sensitive. However, it's common practice to type the commands in all-caps so that it's easier to read the code. Another common practice that you will see is that each command starts on a new line. The code won't break if this isn't done but it's best to write the code the most common way to avoid any potential confusion. Almost every query starts with the SELECT command and an asterix(*) is used to select all columns. Also, each query ends with a semicolon(;). The semicolon signifies to SQL that the query statement is complete so that it can start running the query.

DDL Commands

The previous section mentioned that every query starts with SELECT...except here. Below show the following examples.

CREATE

This includes creating tables and databases.

Follow this syntax to create a table

This includes creating tables and databases.

ALTER TABLE

ALTER TABLE (*table_name*) ADD (Columnname_1 datatype, Columnname_2 datatype, â€¦ Columnname_n datatype);

DROP

The DROP command works with ALTER TABLE in order to select which column isn't needed.

ALTER TABLE (*table_name*) DROP COLUMN (*column_name*);

TRUNCATE

COMMENT

Select Statement

As mentioned in the Syntax section, the SELECT command always starts the query. Meaning that all of the syntaxes shown in this documentation will have SELECT. Here's a quick example...

SELECT * FROM (*table-name*);

Or a certain amount of columns can be selected like this...

SELECT (column1, column2...) FROM (*table-name*);

One or more columns can be selected from one or more tables. Selecting columns from different tables will be described further in the Joins section.

Where & Having

Here is a good way to remember when to use WHERE and HAVING commands from GeeksForGeeks, "It is not a predefined rule but in a good number of the SQL queries, we use WHERE prior to GROUP BY and HAVING after GROUP BY. The Where clause acts as a pre filter where as Having as a post filter."

WHERE

Sets the condition of the data that gets viewed based on what columns are selected. It is based on the data rows in a table. It CAN'T be used with aggregates.

SELECT (*column-names*) FROM (*table-name*) WHERE (*condition*);

HAVING

On the other hand, the HAVING command DOES work on aggregate data. The below example will use the SUM command which is one of the aggregate functions mentioned in the Aggregate Functions section.

SELECT (*column-name*), SUM(*column-name*) AS (*new-column-name*)FROM (*table-name*) GROUP BY (*column-name*);
CRUD Operations

CRUD stands for Create, Read, Update, and Delete. Some of these operations are part of DML(Data Manipulation Language)Commands

CREATE

READ

UPDATE

Keep in mind that the WHERE command is needed for this query to specify which value(s) needs to be changed. Otherwise the whole table will change!

UPDATE table_name SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2, ... WHERE condition;

DELETE

This operation will delete rows that exist. The WHERE operation is important otherwise the whole table will be lost!

DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition;

INSERT INTO

This is used to add new values into an existing table. The values need to be in the same order as how the columns appear in the table from left to right.

INSERT INTO (table-name) VALUES (value1, value2,...etc);
Aggregation Functions

Aggregation is another word of clumping or grouping items together. In the case for SQL and other languages data values would be the items being grouped together. Aggregations functions for SQL are average, count, sum, minimum, and maximum. While reading through some of the other commands, there are some other commands that I think would fit into this category. Those commands are Group By and Order By.

AVG

Finds the average of a numerical column.

SELECT AVG(column_name) FROM table_name WHERE condition;

COUNT

Provides the quantity of the selected column.

SELECT COUNT(column_name) FROM table_name;

SUM

Returns the total of a numerical column.

SELECT SUM(column_name) FROM table_name WHERE condition;

MIN

Returns the lowest value of a numerical column.

SELECT MIN(column_name) FROM table_name WHERE condition;

MAX

Returns the highest value of a numerical column.

SELECT MAX(column_name) FROM table_name WHERE condition;

GROUP BY

This command groups rows that share the same values. It is also often combined with the aggregate functions mentioned right above.

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE condition GROUP BY column_name(s);

ORDER BY

Here's the syntax of ordering the data based off of one column...

SELECT * FROM (*table_name*) ORDER BY (*column_name*) ASC|DESC

And here's how it's done with muliple columns...

SELECT * FROM (*table_name*) ORDER BY (*column1*) ASC|DESC , (*column2*) ASC|DESC
Like, In, Between, Any & All

LIKE

This operator is always used with WHERE.

SELECT (*columnN*) FROM (*table_name*) WHERE (*columnN*) LIKE (*'_' &/OR '%'*);

IN

There's two ways to use IN. Right below shows a selection of multiple values...

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE column_name IN (value1, value2, ...);

This syntax for IN include additional SELECT commands.

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE column_name IN (SELECT STATEMENT);

BETWEEN

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE column_name BETWEEN value1 AND value2;

ANY

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE column_name operator ANY (SELECT column_name FROM table_name WHERE condition);

ALL

There's a couple of ways to use ALL. Right below is a syntax to use ALL with SELECT...

SELECT ALL column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE condition;

this command can also be used with WHERE and HAVING commands like below...

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table_name WHERE column_name operator ALL (SELECT column_name FROM table_name WHERE condition);

AND

This command is similar to conditional commands in other programs. It should be used when both values are true. Multiple AND commands can be added to query what's needed.

SELECT * FROM (*table_name*) WHERE (*condition1*) AND (*condition2*) AND ...;

The conditions that can be used with SQL are: =, <, <=, >=, and >.

OR

This command also works similar to conditional commands in other programs in which either value is true.

SELECT * FROM (*table_name*) WHERE (*condition1*) OR (*condition2*) OR...;

The AND/OR commands can also be combined like so...

SELECT * FROM (*table_name*) WHERE (*condition1*) AND (condition2 OR condition3);

NOT

For values that aren't needed or isn't true...

SELECT column1, column2, ... FROM table_name WHERE NOT condition;
SubQueries

Joins & Unions

Inner Join

Joining two tables

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1 INNER JOIN table2 ON table1.column_name = table2.column_name;

Multiple tables can be joined together by repeating the join type and ON command.

Right Join

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1 RIGHT JOIN table2 ON table1.column_name = table2.column_name;

Left Join

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1 LEFT JOIN table2 ON table1.column_name = table2.column_name;

Self Join

SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1 T1, table1 T2 WHERE condition;

UNION

To get started with writing JavaScript, open the Scratchpad and write your first "Hello world" JavaScript code:

function greetMe(yourName) { alert("Hello " + yourName); } greetMe("World");

Select the code in the pad and hit Ctrl+R to watch it unfold in your browser!
